Slice vs map for set in golang

Date: 15 Aug 2015
Author: Erik Dubbelboer

Ever wonder if itâ€™s faster to use a slice or map to represent a set in go? I wrote the following program to find out:

And here is the output:

$ ./bench.sh
1       -261.887532ms
2       -283.816189ms
3       -180.629338ms
4       -273.558558ms
5       -170.395637ms
6       -110.11527ms
7       -238.179383ms
8       -86.595302ms
9       -386.665905ms
10      -230.164293ms
11      -240.030718ms
12      -310.295027ms
13      -183.209792ms
14      -172.458055ms
15      -210.97313ms
16      -130.370425ms
17      -134.322002ms
18      37.839305ms
19      49.001029ms
20      35.248726ms
21      158.058773ms
22      231.8019ms
23      1.846585ms
24      39.449983ms
25      33.189299ms

Conclusion

As you can see, for less than 18 elements a slice seems to be faster than a map.

Here is the resulting set that I wrote: github.com/ErikDubbelboer/set

The out of place timings you see around 7, 15 and 23 probably have to do with the number of elements go stores per bucket. But I havenâ€™t had the time to look into this.
